results.title: The Eel = Unagi
results.creator_credit: Shohei Imamura, Hisa Lino, Imamura Productions, KSS Films, Satellite Cinema and Shochiku
results.brief_description: The Eel begins with the main character - Takuro Yamashita (Koji Yakusho) coming home early from a fishing trip to catch his wife committing adultery. He stabs her to death and then hands himself in to the police. The credits to the film commence, where it is revealed that Yamashita has just been released after eight years in prison. He carries with him a pet eel who has been his main companion in prison. Yamashita buys a dilapidated barber shop in a small rural town where he assumes he will be left alone. Soon, however, he is befriended by the assorted local characters who hang around his shop. Then he saves the life of Keiko Hattori (Misa Shimizu), a woman attempting to commit suicide to escape her manipulative fiance and her mad mother - and who also happens to resemble his murdered wife. The lives of these two escapees soon become entwined. Winner of the 1997 Cannes Palme d’Or, Shohei Imamura’s film masterfully balances humour and surreal imagery with a tale of redemption and love. The film bristles with the tension of Yamashita’s constant potential for violence and the surprising comical twists of his journey. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: Nights of Cabiria = Le Notti di Cabiria
results.creator_credit: Federico Fellini, Dino De Laurentiis and De Laurentiis Entertainment Group
results.brief_description: Nights of Cabiria is Fellini’s bitter-sweet account of a resilient Roman prostitute desperate to find love and respect in marriage. Cabiria, played by Fellini’s wife Giulietta Masina, is the prostitute with a heart of gold who is in love with love. Endlessly searching for true love, Cabiria is continually disappointed by men - abused, deceived and betrayed - but she never loses hope. In Italian with English subtitles.

results.title: Trauma
results.brief_description: A mysterious 16 year old girl named Aura (played by Dario Argento’s daughter Asia) is saved from jumping off a bridge by David, a young graphic artist (Christopher Rydell). The troubled girl has just escaped from a sanatorium run by the sinister Dr. Judd (Frederick Forrest) and is terrified about going back there. Meanwhile a deranged killer who gruesomely dispatches his victims by decapitation is terrorizing the city. Aura finds herself safely back at her parents, an odd pair of Russian mystics (Piper Laurie and Dominique Serrand) but soon finds her life is in danger as the killer is somehow linked to her past. Argento’s delirious thriller threatens to derail at certain times, mixing explicit violence, eating disorders, romance and mysticism. However his stylish direction holds it together for the most part, only faltering right at the end with a ludicrous and extraneous credit sequence. Cast also includes Brad Dourif, James Russo and Laura Johnson. See also ‘Deep red’ (1975), ‘Suspiria’ (1977) and ‘The Bird with the crystal plumage’ (1970).

results.title: Suspiria [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Dario Argento, Claudio Argento and La Seda
results.brief_description: Presented in widescreen, this un-cut version of Dario Argento’s ‘Suspiria’ is the first part (1980’s ‘Inferno’ being the follow up) in an as yet to be complete trilogy called “The Three mothers”. Susy Banyon (Jessica Harper), an American Ballet student travels to Germany to attend the exclusive Tanz Academy in Frieburg. Legend goes that the ancient school was once the residence of a witches coven, headed by an evil and powerful black witch named Mater Suspiriorum (Black Widow). When a series of grisly murders begin to occur at the ballet school, Susy begins to suspect that witchcraft may be involved. Working at the height of his creative powers (following the box office success of 1975’s ‘Deep Red’) Argento raises the level of terror with his trademark blood soaked set pieces by using vibrant colour film stock, abrupt editing, multi-layered sound scapes (including the techno-rock Goblin score) and rapid camera movement. Cast also includes Alida Valli, Udo Kier, Stefania Casini, Joan Bennett, Flavio Bucci, Miguel Bose, Barbara Magnolfi and Susanna Javicoli.

constellations_other.name: What's in a name?
constellations_other.description: Pakeezah (1972) star Meena Kumari was not just 'the tragedy queen' of Hindi film – she also wrote poetry under the pseudonym Naaz. From famous families and stage names to gendered disguises, this Constellation explores how women have adopted different names and identities to facilitate their ambition.

results.title: Chronicle of a love = Loving lie
results.brief_description: Antonioni’s highly acclaimed first film relates the tale of an adulterous wife and her impoverished lover who plan to murder her rich husband. He dies before they carry out the deed and they have to live with the guilt of their intentions. In Italian with English subtitles.

results.title: Marriage Italian style = Matrimonio all'Italiano
results.creator_credit: Vittorio De Sica, Carlo Ponti and Embassy Pictures Corporation (US)
results.brief_description: In flashback, Don Domenico recalls his wartime romance with Filumena. He is so enamoured with her that he finances her escape from the bordello where she lives and works, and sets her up as manager of his business. Later, he finds a place for her as his mother’s domestic help. Whilst he continues to provide for her, he is not interested in making their union legal, expecting her to act as servant by day and mistress by night. Years later, Filumena lies on her deathbed, and Don Domenico finally consents to marry her, only to find she makes a full recovery immediately after the vows have been taken. He tries to weasel his way out of this fraudulent arrangement, but is mollified by Filumena’s insistence that one of her three sons is his. Cast includes Sofia Loren and Marcello Mastroianni. It Italian with English subtitles.

results.title: The Fifth element (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Luc Besson, Patrick Ledoux, Columbia and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description: The Fifth Element takes an amazing glimpse into the future, with wonderful visual effects from the people who gave us “Titanic”, “Nikita” and “The Professional”, and unique costumes by visionary designer, Jean-Paul Gaultier. If the four elements are fire, water, earth and air, what is the Fifth element? What does it do? Who has control of it? These questions and others are answered as the film unfolds at a breath taking pace. This film takes you on a sci-fi thrill ride of the decade. Bruce Willis, a taxi-driver in New York city in the 23rd Century is selected as our hero. He will travel to the end of the galaxy to decide the fate of our universe. Cast includes Gary Oldman, Milla Jovovich, Ian Holm and Chris Tucker.

results.title: The Castle (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Rob Sitch, Debra Choate and Working Dog
results.brief_description: How Darryl Kerrigan, average working joe, and his small time suburban lawyer mate, Denis Denuto ended up in the High Court of Australia is the story told in ‘The Castle’. The Kerrigan family live at 3 Highview Crescent, Cooloroo, on the edge of an international airport, in total obscurity. That is until the consortium owning the airport decide to expand and the land surrounding the airport is to be compulsorily acquired from the residents. What the powers-that-be did not count on was the dogged determination of Darryl Kerrigan, greyhound racer, tow-truck driver with a keen eye for a bargain, to whom his house is his family’ home and a very happy one at that. Ordinary family.

results.title: While the city sleeps
results.creator_credit: Fritz Lang, Burt Friedlob and RKO Radio Pictures
results.brief_description: The editorship of a major city newspaper comes to rest upon the search for a psychopathic murderer (the “lipstick killer”). Although widely dismissed or neglected by critics, this is a film which Lang regarded as equal to his classic ‘M’. Thematically it bears comparison in the implication that socially acceptable levels of society are little different from the noir underworld. The murderer is more sympathetic than the newspaper people. There are also explicit parallels between the murderer and the ‘hero’ played by Dana Andrews, who at one stage uses his girlfriend as ‘bait’ for the killer. Stylistically this is Lang at his most lucidly refined. Cast includes Dana Andrews, George Sanders, Rhonda Fleming, George Sanders, Vincent Price and Ida Lupino. Based on the novel “The Bloody Spur” by Charles Einstein.

results.title: Pandora's box = Die Buchse der Pandora = Lulu
results.brief_description: A chronicle of the last months of Lulu’s life has been extracted from Wedekind’s play with more emphasis on thematic and psychological continuity than dramatic unity. Pabst portrays a gallery of characters ranging from the masochistic Schon to the compulsively psychotic Jack the Ripper - and Countess Geschwitz, the screen’s first unequivocal lesbian - with psychological acuity. Lulu, guileless and sexually ambiguous, is to Tony Rayns “the literal calm eye of the storm”. Further, Brooks’s performance is “passive” yet vital, suspended with candour and precision between innocence and childishly fleeting - but intense - emotions. Her emotional vitality and Pabst’s unobtrusive cutting on action make Pandora the most “modern” of silent classics. Cast includes Louise Brooks, Fritz Kortner, Franz Lederer, Carl Goetz, Carl Raschig and Alice Roberts. Adapted from Wedekind’s plays “Erdgeist” and “Die Buchse der Pandora”. Review by Tony Rayns, Monthly Film Bulletin, May 1974.
